abstract.p: Negotiators for baseball owners and players hold series of meetings on Oct 19 in effort to reach labor agreement (S)

block.p: The rain that washed out Game 1 of the World Series did not deter negotiators seeking a labor agreement for baseball, who went back and forth between each other's Manhattan offices yesterday in an effort to work out the few remaining issues.

''We have had a series of meetings, and we're continuing our discussion from yesterday,'' Donald Fehr, the players' union chief, said during a break in his talks with Randy Levine, the owners' chief negotiator.

The rain that washed out Game 1 of the World Series did not deter negotiators seeking a labor agreement for baseball, who went back and forth between each other's Manhattan offices yesterday in an effort to work out the few remaining issues.

''We have had a series of meetings, and we're continuing our discussion from yesterday,'' Donald Fehr, the players' union chief, said during a break in his talks with Randy Levine, the owners' chief negotiator.

Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, is expected to arrive in New York today to attend the postponed game and it is virtually impossible owners would ratify any agreement Selig did not like. Owner approval requires a three-fourths majority, or 21 votes from the 28 clubs.
